page.title: 01The History Of Alsager
page.content: Alsager is situated in the S.E. corner of Cheshire. It covers an area of over 2000 acres and has a population of 11,600. In the original Domesday Book it is quoted as being owned by the Earl of Chester. Before 1066 it belonged to an Anglo Saxon called Uluric, and the area payed very little tax. We are also told the farm land was only sufficient for one oxen to plough in one season, and that most of the land was waste - worth one shilling in tax. During the 18th C a church was built. In the 19th C the railway was built and many pottery managers and workers started to live in Alsager. Since WW2 improved transport - M6 and rail links plus accessiblity to Manchester - airport, Wales and the North have made it a popular place to live.
